awd_titl_txt: Analyses of Large-scale Climate Variability: Understanding Periodicity in the Extratropical Storm Tracks
awd_abstract_narration:
Weather systems appearing on daily maps are driven by the temperature contrast between the tropics and the poles, which is expressed dynamically as the baroclinicity of the atmosphere, or the variation of pressure on surfaces of constant density.  Pressure differences on density surfaces produce a pressure gradient force, which provides the kinetic energy that powers weather systems and the winds associated with them.  Recently the PI demonstrated that the interplay between baroclinicity and kinetic energy (in this case referred to as eddy kinetic energy or EKE), results in variations in the vigor of weather activity with a period between 20 and 25  days (see AGS-1343080).  The 20-25 day oscillation was documented in the longitudinally averaged EKE of the Southern Hemisphere and has an annular structure with peak amplitude near the center of the storm track.  The mode is thus referred to as the Southern Baroclinic Annular Mode (SBAM), and the PI has identified a comparable although weaker counterpart, the NBAM, in the Northern Hemisphere.

Work funded here seeks to develop a physical understanding of the modes, using a combination of observational data analysis and model simulations to understand why the modes exist and what determines their periodicity, spatial structure, relationship to individual weather systems, and other characteristics. The work also considers the implications of the modes for practical weather forecasting, in part by examining their predictability in the forecasts archived as part of the Seasonal to Subseasonal Prediction Project (performed under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organization).

The research is of societal as well as scientific interest due to the possible implications of predictable oscillations in weather activity for long-range forecasting.  The PI and his group also perform outreach to the local school district through presentations to students and teachers on the science of weather and climate.  In addition, the project supports two graduate students, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the proposed research was to improve our physical understanding of week to week variability in extratropical climate variability, with an emphasis on understanding periodicity in extratropical storms and the processes that govern such behavior. The work included research streams focused on 1) Probing two-way interactions between extratropical storms and the atmospheric flow in observations; 2) Exploring the physics whereby extratropical storms interact with the surface and atmospheric baroclinicity; 3) The physics whereby extratropical storms interact with the stratospheric flow; and 4) The influence of periodic variability in extratropical storms on surface climate. 

The project provided either partial or full support for 19 research papers published in the peer-reviewed literature.  The papers led to new insights into the zonal structure of the annular modes; the physics of the baroclinic annular mode/periodicity in the flow; the physics of "downstream suppression", which is a key ingredient of periodicity in the extratropical flow; two-way relationships between variations in Kuroshio- Oyashio Extension sea surface temperatures and the atmospheric circulation over the North Pacific, with implications for periodicity in that sector of the hemisphere; and the role of atmospheric and oceanic processes in driving variations in surface baroclinicity over ocean areas. 

The papers resulting from the project also revealed the role of various cloud radiative effects in driving variations in the atmospheric flow, with implications for interpreting the two-way feedbacks between the atmospheric flow and atmospheric temperatures; provided insights into the response of the extratropical circulation to variations in the damping of temperature anomalies; demonstrated the role of the stratosphere in driving weather over various parts of the Southern Hemisphere - and for prediction of the surface flow - on the intraseasonal timescales essential for the project; and documented the linkages between the southern baroclinic annular mode and Antarctic surface climate.

The project provided training and professional development for four graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher. The development included mentoring from the PI, mentoring from student committee members, travel to numerous domestic and international conferences for all project members, presentations at group meetings, and presentations and interacting with scientists at NCAR. 

The results were disseminated through publications, seminars at various institutes, and presentations at multiple conferences. 

The broader impacts of the project included the training of graduate student and postdoctoral researchers for careers in the climate sciences. They also included new insights into the processes that drive extratropical weather on sub-seasonal to seasonal timescales and thus for weather prediction beyond the limit of deterministic weather forecasts. Prediction on such "S2S" timescales has widespread implications for society.
